metadata.h1: Why should you care about particle physics?

all_paragraphs: We’re sitting in the train, heading to work. I’m studying a research paper while you muster me up and down.
‘Why did you become a particle physicist?’
‘Because I enjoy it,’ I reply bluntly.
‘Yeah but — your job is funded by the government. So obviously there should be some public interest in what you’re doing?’
‘Yes, of course. Science is always of public interest. That’s because it’s deeply human to be curious about how the world works. And science is the best way to find out!’
‘Of course, but shouldn’t we be targeting bigger problems with science? There are more important things than funny little particles! Cancer, humanitarian crises, wars…’
The science of today is the technology of tomorrow
‘You’re right,’ I admit. ‘Of course those problems are much more pressing, and we should definitely fund scientists and organizations to try to solve them.
‘But we should also fund particle physicists. Think about it: Einstein published his theory of relativity more than a century ago. Yet without it, we wouldn’t have GPS today!’

‘Well, GPS works with satellites that orbit around the Earth. Your position on Earth is calculated from the distance that each of these satellites have to your device. But you need to take into account that they orbit around Earth pretty fast. Einstein’s theory predicts that time ticks a little faster for objects that move rapidly. If we wouldn’t take that into account, GPS would be so inaccurate that you could hardly make use of it.’
‘Oh, wow. So if the government hadn’t funded Einstein to do his theories, we’d still be using maps without our current position?’

‘In fact, you’d have GPS anyway. Einstein is quite an exception — he did his physics research in his spare time while he was working as a patent attorney. He didn’t get any funding for developing his theories.’
‘See? You’re obsolete!’ you blurt out with a sheepish grin on your face.
‘Well, no! Without funding for particle physics, we wouldn’t have the World Wide Web.’
‘You heard me right. The WWW was invented by particles physicists at CERN.’
‘Those guys must be geniuses. Why weren’t they concentrating on their particles though?’

‘You see,’ I begin, ‘at CERN, a huge amount of data is produced every year. And a lot of researchers only stay at CERN for a year or two, and then continue to work on their projects from their home laboratories. So the scientists developed a system with which they could access information from anywhere. Et voilà, the World Wide Web was born!’
I smile. ‘Yes, hadn’t that happened thirty years ago, the world might be a very different place today.’
‘Okay but that’s a while ago. So why are people still working there today? Aren’t we wasting our money?’
‘Well, first of all, we’re still curious about elementary particles. That’s the main motivation. The Higgs boson has been discovered, but there’s still a lot of mysteries that we’d like to solve.

‘Plus, this tool of particle physics, called World Wide Web, reached a very widespread use. New tools are constantly being developed in and around CERN. Why shouldn’t those be useful to the public, too?’
‘What kind of tools would those be?’

‘Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence, for example. Particle physicists are among the earliest developers and adopters of these technologies. They help to make sense of the enormous amounts of data they gather.’
‘So particle physics is, like, a lot of data science?’

‘Exactly. And that’s why particle physicists at CERN and all over the world are on the cutting edge when it comes to developing these algorithms. That doesn’t mean that they’re the only ones — there are lots of computer scientists, data engineers and others involved, too.

‘But particle physicists are really helping to move this field forward because they need these tools for their work on particle data. We’re still at the very beginnings — but you can expect AI to change the world in similar ways as the World Wide Web did.’

‘We’ll see whether that happens… Speaking about technological revolutions, there’s also Quantum Computing. That could also be important in the future, right? Do particle physicists work on that, too?’

‘Not that much. Quantum physics has a lot to do with particle physics, but they’re not the same. At the same time, Quantum Computing, and especially the Quantum Internet, might revolutionize scientific computing as a whole. Particle physicists could profit from that, as well as many many other branches of science. And who knows what kind of technological and societal advances will result from that?’
‘Yeah, who knows?’ you reply, gazing out of the window. ‘That does sound quite cool. Seems like particle physics plays quite a large role in everybody’s lives, but in ways that you wouldn’t expect.’
‘You’re perfectly right,’ I reply, smiling contently as we move towards the door to exit the train.
